repnme.cdata!: Honduras - Fourth Social Investment Fund Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the Fourth Social
            Investment Fund for Honduras were as follows: the outcome
            was satisfactory, the sustainability was likely, the
            institutional development impact wqas substantial, the Bank
            performance was highly satisfactory, and the borrower
            performance was satisfactory. The lessons learned indicate
            that the response of Honduras Social Investment Fund (FHIS)
            and IDA to the Mitch catastrophe showed the major role that
            Social Investment Funds (SIFs) can play in such emergency
            situations because of their unique design and procedures.
            This flexibility, largely a function of the fact that its
            operating procedures are determined in an Operations Manual
            that can usually be adapted with minimal bureaucratic
            transactions makes it well suited to responding in
            unforeseen circumstances. FHIS's decision to set up
            nine regional offices with delegated responsibilities and
            resources facilitated its rapid response to local hurricane
            repair needs. With the road and telecommunications
            infrastructure severely damaged by Mitch, having
            decision-makers at the field level was essential. The
            decentralized offices allowed FHIS to develop a productive,
            collaborative relationship with the municipal governments
            and communities. Based on the Mitch experience, it is
            recommended that all SIFs and their respective governments
            agree on what the SIF's role should be in the event of
            a national disaster. This role should be clearly defined in
            a detailed emergency operating manual (i.e., contingency
            procedures) that simplifies the project cycle, while
            ensuring transparent and efficient project management. This
            project shows the reality of doing what is necessary in an
            emergency situation. Speed and responsiveness can cause
            drawbacks that need to be recognized, but are often
            unavoidable. Future operations should recognize that the
            transition back to normal operations can be facilitated by
            an up front limitation on the volume and timetable of
            emergency subprojects. When SIFs are involved in an
            emergency, it may be appropriate to also consider a response
            to social needs unrelated to infrastructure. The Bank showed
            the capacity to respond immediately to the Mitch crisis and
            adapt to new needs. A dramatic change in project approach
            requires intensive Bank staff involvement at many levels
            ranging from approving new operating procedures, pursuing
            supplemental financing, and providing close technical
            assistance. FHIS worked through ethnic umbrella
            organizations, the federations, to reach targeted minority
            groups. Based on this experience, the concept of community
            banks (Cajas Rurales) should be cultivated among groups of
            communities, rather than at the level of each community, in
            order to make the funds more sustainable.

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Fourth Social
            Investment Fund Project are: (a) to increase access among
            the poor to small-scale social and economic infrastructure
            in accordance with local development priorities; (b) to
            develop social assistance programs for disadvantaged groups;
            and (c) to contribute to the prospects for sustainability of
            such investments. The project components include: (a)
            subproject financing for social and economic infrastructure
            subprojects and special programs such as social assistance
            and programs for indigenous communities; (b) a pilot program
            for local institutional strengthening; (c) a pilot program
            to strengthen community and rural water systems; and (d)
            project management.
